original_content:
Power delivery in passenger vehicle drivetrains hasnt changed much since the introduction of the continuously variable (CV) joint in the 1930s. Most electric vehicles still deliver power via the same system used by internal combustion cars. Hyundai/Kia has now revealed a system they think will provide a new paradigm with their Universal Wheel Drive System (Uni Wheel). [via Electrek]
What appears at first to be a hub motor is in fact a geared wheel that keeps the motor close without the problem of high unsprung weight. Power is fed into a sun gear which can move independently of the wheel allowing the system to maintain a more consistent driveline and avoid power variability over the range of suspension travel like youd find in a CV joint experiencing high deflection.
We have some concerns about the durability of such a system when compared with the KISS and long development history of CV joints, but we cant deny that moving the motors of an electric vehicle out to the corners would allow more packaging flexibility for the cargo and passenger areas. Were also excited to see open source replicas make their way into smaller robotics projects now that the images have been released. If youve already made one in CAD, send us a tip at tips@hackaday.com.
Looking for more interesting innovations in electric cars? How about an off-grid camper van? If you think automakers are overcomplicating something that should be simple, read the Minimal Motoring Manifesto.
title: ヒュンダイ/キアが新しいパラダイムを提供する「ユニバーサルホイールドライブシステム（Uni Wheel）」を発表
body: ヒュンダイ/キアが、Uni Wheelと呼ばれる新しい駆動システムを開発。ハブモーターのように見えるが、ハイブリッド車両のように一定のトルクを保っている。耐久性には疑問があるが、荷物や乗客スペースに柔軟性が生まれる可能性がある。
